Title: Learn you some Erlang for great good!
Author: Fred Hebert

Title: Inferno
Author: Dante Alighieri
My Review:
This was an allegorical masterpiece. A master of poetry places his deep knowledge and understanding of religion, literature, politics and human psychology behind the curtains of skilfully crafted passages.

We can all place ourselves in Dante's shoes. Since our divine intellect is easily corruptible by our senses we can all find ourselves in the dark forrest searching for the rightful path.

Dante chose Virgil as his guide as Virgil already envisioned a trip through hell via Aeneas in the Aeneid.

Terrible monsters and guardians such as Minos, Crete's king, Cerbereustry, Charon and others, try to stop their trip, but Virgil repremands them by signaling that Dante's path has been granted a stamp of approval by the "One who wills".

Caught me by surprise that non-Christians are on the first circle of hell, however appreciated the fact people such as Socrates are able to live the afterlife they envisioned during their lifetime.

Some symbolical pairings or sin and scene made a lasting impression on me.


Lustful on circle 2 are brown around by wind ad they don't have control over their behaviour.

The gluttonous on circle 3 live in horrid conditions as a pig

The wrathful on level 4 who didn't express wrath and kept it to themselves are drowning in the Styx with no one hearing what they are trying to convey underwater.

The sodomites on level 7 live in rain of fire and scorching land. Rain is supposed to stimulate the fertile soil produce vegetation. As sodomy does not produce offsprings, the same goes for the rain of fire and scorching earth.

In general, I enjoyed the way spirits are punished. With the opposite of what they tried to achieve on earth. I loved how Dante despite feeling pity at the start, progressively grew more disdainful of sin and stopped pitting the spirits.

I loved when right before the two poets descend to the ninth circle they see all the chained Giants. The first giant is called Nimrod, he built the tower of Babel and is talking gibberish. Virgil repremands him and tells him he is a dimwit. Found that incredibly funny.

Title: Genesis (Bible, #1)
Author: Anonymous
My Review:
Combined with the biblical lectures of Peterson, the lectures of Jonathan Peageau, lectures of Paul Vanderklay and the book "Jordan Peterson, God, and Christianity
THE SEARCH FOR A MEANINGFUL LIFE" Genesis book is actually mind opening. It was a great introduction to my first steps into being an Orthodox Christian. It gave me much insight into some of my questioning towards what god is, how i should behave as a christian, why i should initially blindly follow orthodox traditions, how i should perceive the covenants with god, but most of all it helped me start believing in God. As thomas Aquinas brillaintly says how we have two wings. On one aide we have god, on the other we have rationality. They need to walk side by side.

Title: Jordan Peterson, God, and Christianity: The Search for a Meaningful Life
Author: Christopher Kaczor

Title: Кант и свободният избор (Философия за всеки, #7)
Author: София Петрова
My Review:
Another great summary by Sofia Petrova. Kant's short life stories give a great representation of what this man truly was. His ideas of the critical and practical mind. His experiences with friends and acquaintances. His strict way of live and views on life, death, friendship, free will, behaviour, virtue show how this man was the first professional philosopher and how he gave start to German philosophy in the 18th century. He was also the root cause of the raise of Idealism and Romantism in the 19th century.

What made the biggest impression on me was his simple explanation on a moral and virtuous life. In simple theory we fight over our instincts, wants, wills and before we act on it we run through our rational mind, if the latter approves then we can safely go on if not we fight over our desire. But in practice it's the most difficult thing a man can accomplish.

"Women want control. Men want self-control"

Title: Ницше и волята за власт
Author: София Петрова
My Review:
A great summary of Nietzsche's life and ideas through brief stories from his adolescence to adulthood.

Amor fati, Thus Spoke Zarathustra, the uber mensch, the death of the gods, friendship with Wagner, love with Lu Salome, his ideas on nihilism, sympathy, the moral philosopher, death, life, friendships, the pursuit of power, the power of music, the idea of virtue, Nietzsche vs Kant. All of this ideas are briefly explored and give the reader exactly what he needs to an i troduction to this extraordinary man who stayed committed to his ideas until his breakdown, coma and subsequent heart attack.

Title: The Art of War
Author: Sun Tzu
My Review: The three fundamentals are know yourself, know the enemy and know the terrain. These can be further diversified. It mentions the mentality of the leader, of the commanders and the soldiers. It also explains how to attack by using fire and how to use spies to their best abilities.

Title: Rich Dad, Poor Dad
Author: Robert T. Kiyosaki
My Review:
This book could have been shortened to 20 pages. But it's definitely worth a read. Throughout the entire time it motivates you to think about how u can make some "Active" income.

Best advice I saw in the book:

- Keep thinking, just to keep your brain active in finding new opportunities whether that's exploring the properties market or reading a book on investing.

- Understanding how owning a firm would help you get back some taxes. I would find a friend who has a firm and order something, run it through the company and get back tax. (Depends on your location)

- Diversify your investments(Stocks, Bonds, Crypto)

- Start thinking about your pension

- Explore the idea of owning a business.

- Keep your emotions separate. Keep calm.

- All in all this book teaches you about what your mindset should be and I believe its a great book for a highscooler.

DISLIKES

- However, I disliked how he says MLM are a good thing and you should strive for it, despite me knowing some people who are highly successful at it, but if its not for you, it's not for you.

- There is too much repetition of everything.

- After double checking not everything is a true representation of his experience. Some things are mentioned as real life experience, but are made up.

- Studies have shown that people who have a mid level jobs are happier than people who own a business.

- Money does definitely not bring you happiness, despite a psychologist once telling me that most people's depression and problems come from not having money.

- Robert failed in the financial business company world. He was living out his car before these series of books exploded.

- He was never poor, mom was a nurse, dad was an academic.

I would strongly advise to avoid buying his seminars, games and possibly other books. The golden knowledge is not here my friends.

Title: Brave New World
Author: Aldous Huxley
My Review:
In this novel we have a comparison between the world of sacrifice, pain and spiritual progress to the one of painless and pleasurable existence. John cannot merge with the new society and is defeated by it. By succumbing to the pleasure he hates himself and ultimately commits suicide.

Another view would suggest that by removing pain from existence the governemnt of the brave new world has charged people with their autonomy. Is this a price we are willing to pay?

Title: The Black Obelisk
Author: Erich Maria Remarque
My Review: The book captures Germany between the two world wars. The crushing defeat after the 1st, the incomparable inflation which followed and along with other misfortunes caused the rise of nazism. Our protagonist Ludwig is a dreamer, a man of art and philosophy. He does not fit with the time he was born in. A time of defeatist mentality, daily anxiety, sad and bewildered people. Death is amongst the entire German population and what best way to explore it than to place Ludwig a WW1 veteran, as a person working in a tombstone company. A place where he can examine death at close sight. Seeing how a person reacts in the face of death can teach you everything about his true character. Along with several other characters they act crazy with actions and dialog, which is a necessity when you live in crazy times. The most memorable moments in the book for me were his discussions with Isabella. A girl who he meets in a psychiatric hospital after she has developed schizophrenia following her traumatic early years.

Title: White Nights
Author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
My Review:
The short story describes a loner roming the streets of Dostoyevsky's city St Petersburg. Looking and examining people whose path he crosses, despite shying away from conversation he can truly feel the others emotions and be as well as happy and sad with them. He finally meets, despite in an unfortunate setting the protagonist's companion(Nastyenka) with whom they find comfort and fight through conversations the lonely nights.

Despite the protagonist never finding love or even having a romantic relationship he has a very adult and deep understanding of the malleable type of love we all seem to admire and be infatuated with. This is best shown when after having made plans for their future Nastyenka gives up everything I a few moments after her old flame and love returns. The protagonist has symathzed with her and began to love her, however decides that her halpibess weights over his needs and wants.

Title: The Art of Loving
Author: Erich Fromm
My Review: I loved this book. It started by giving examples of motherly, brotherly(biblical), fatherly, erotic and god love. It showed how ideological(marxist) or capitalist societal structures define and influence people's view of love. The book also went deep into the parent-child relationship and how it influences the child's perception of love. I loved all the examples of people who had not developed fully into a grown up because of the selfish view of the parent. One great example was the man badly i fluenced by his mother(Carl Jung's puer aeternus). The book finishes off with practical love and explains how the three key principles(discipline, concentration and patience) can be respected, believed in and integrated into our daily activities.

Title: Man’s Search for Meaning
Author: Viktor E. Frankl
Additional Authors: Harold S. Kushner, William J. Winslade, Isle Lasch

Title: The Undiscovered Self
Author: C.G. Jung
My Review:
Firstly, what i loved most about this book was how the self was diminished among societal presence. Plays great with the quote by George Carlin which went along like this "I love the individual. Beautiful, inspiring, interesting. But i hate him/her when they become become a group".

Secondly, the part about psychosis tearing the self into two parts. 1. What the individual is. 2 what the individual think he/het should be hit home like never before.

Finally, I loved how he says that there is a huge difference between Religion(Following god from above) and faith(Following a set of rules for behaviour on earth).

Title: The Denial of Death
Author: Ernest Becker
My Review:
In general Becker says that our whole civilization is the first step to a self-deluding justified denial of death. The denial is at the core of our being. Its what lets us carry on after the realization of our fragile and Camuean absurd lives. That makes sense when we put that into the context of conflict. If we take religion for example. When we have 2 conflicting ideologies, people on both sides will try to argue that the other one is fake as the oposing view is a threat to their own "Denial of Death". So far so good. He carries on to explain how all of us have an "immortality system" which arises from our civilization. Any groups we join, any idea we start to believe in, this is what we believe will continue to work after we have died. In a way we help something continue after us. We are fighting for a higher cause. Nevertheless, all of that is a mask behind our unwillingness to confront death as something which awaits us. This is the mistake Becker tries to show us. He supports Kirkegard's explanation of the man who has truly accepted himself for the fragile and limited being which he is and has become content with that. Accept the absurd, live it, but do not confuse yourself that you have surpassed death. That denial is the reason for so much of the world's pain and misery. No wonder it leads to conflict. Becker does not provide a solution, but in the ideology of the Buddhista we can see that they follow Kirkegard's argument. 1.understand u suffer.
2. One of the seasons for many people to suffer is the denial.
3. The truth that we can free ourselves from it.
4. The path which leads to the end of suffering.

In my own eyes we need to accept that there is no higher cause. We will eventually die and nothing matters in the grand scheme of things. We need to feel the anxiety, accept ourselves and battle the absurdity of it on a daily basis.

Becker suggest some sort of a "faith" towards the devine cosmic plan. In a way blind faith, which tells us that we need to accept the fact we will never be able to attain true meaning.

Let's get back to the calmity with which Becker wants us to attain the acceptance of death. He mentions Socrates when he is called up to court for corrupting the youth and how he irritates the jury by not being frightened by the consequences. I personally remembered "The Man" in Nicola Vaptsarov's "The song about a man" and Carlos Fuentes' "The death of Artemio Cruz". Both heroes were in the same predicament,but they courageously and calmy(Artemio) or smiling and accepting(The man) faced death.


To be continued...

Title: The Death of Artemio Cruz
Author: Carlos Fuentes
My Review:
A great book which depics the memories of a man lying on his deathbed. The main theme in the book is the battle between choices. Some people make choices which help them survive, however we can see such a man trying to make sense and live with his choices, unlike his son for example which in a romantic fashion risks everything to die for his ideology and his beloved ones.

Fuentes also shows how the Mexican revolution changes people's mindsets after all the blood which has been shed. The revolutionaries are tired, old, low in numbers and the rest try to play out the revotion for their own benefit.
